title: LAYING DOWN YOUR LIFE FOR THE SHEEP Part 1
scripture_text:
I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the
sheep. The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep. So
when he sees the wolf coming, he abandons the sheep and runs away. Then
the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it. The man runs away because he
is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep. "I am the good
shepherd; I know my sheep and my sheep know me---just as the Father
knows me and I know the Father---and I lay down my life for the sheep.
I have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring
them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one
flock and one shepherd. The reason my Father loves me is that I lay down
my life---only to take it up again. No one takes it from me, but I lay
it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority
to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.
devotional:
John 10 is one of the best-loved chapters of the bible; for many
Christians it has been a chapter that has brought much comfort and
encouragement. Verses like, 'I have come that they may have life, and
have it to the full, 10:10 or I give them eternal life, and they shall
never perish; no one can snatch them out of my hand.' 10:28

The problem is because it is so well known we are inclined to come to
it with our assumptions. When Jesus first spoke these words they were
not intended to be a source of comfort or encouragement, rather they
were a challenge against the bad shepherding practices of the Pharisees
and the religious leaders of His day.

To help us understand the context we need to go back and just take a
quick look at the last few verse of chapter 9;40,41 Some Pharisees
who were with him heard him say this and asked, "What? Are we blind
too?" Jesus said, "If you were blind, you would not be guilty of
sin; but now that you claim you can see, your guilt remains."

In those verses we are given a moral infantry of the Pharisees who
were bad shepherds of Gods people. The interesting thing about these
verses is that Jesus does not talk about the 'activities' of the bad
shepherds or their theology, but their characters.

A bad shepherd is someone who refuses to be honest with themselves.
Look at the question they asked Jesus. 'What? Are we blind too?' John
9:40. This is a very interesting question that reveals a lot about the
Pharisees. They were unable to evaluate their own lives; they lived in
denial, and could not cope with reality. They were blind to their
blindness. They were unable to correctly evaluate their own spiritual
condition. They found comfort in lying to themselves about themselves.
Often people find it easier to deal with other peoples problems than
deal with their own, this is a common form of denial and
self-deception.

A bad shepherd is some one who has a confused morality. Jesus said in
response to the Pharisees question, "If you were blind you would not be
guilty of sin." In other words your claim not to be blind makes you more
calculable for your sin. Because you think you have spiritual insight
and understanding, you are more more guilty of sin. Any refusal on our
part to make honest and spiritual evaluations about ourselves will
result in us having wrong perceptions and making wrong judgements about
others.

A bad shepherd is one that lives under guilt.

Jesus concludes in verse 41 with saying 'but now that you claim you
can see, your guilt remains.' Jesus is not speaking here about being
motivated by guilt; rather he is speaking about living under the
condemnation of God. To live under condemnation in essence means that a
person has no freedom, they are condemned, and they are slaves to
something or some one. Without freedom we will not be able to serve
others.

The bad shepherd is someone who lacks honesty, morality and freedom.

These people may not have set out with the intention of being bad in
the sense that they are unable to implement good pastoral care for
others, rather their bad shepherding is the symptomatic and spontaneous
result of their character. They were unable to do the good things that a
good shepherd should do, not because they were uninformed about the
responsibilities of a shepherd. Rather, because of a flaw in their
characters they were unwilling or unable to fulfil the role of a 'good
shepherd.'
prayer:
Father,'Help me to develop the character of a good
Shephard.'

LAYING DOWN YOUR LIFE FOR THE SHEEP Part 1

John 10:11-18.

I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep. The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep. I have authority to lay it down and authority to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.

To help us understand the context we need to go back and just take a quick look at the last few verse of chapter 9;40,41 Some Pharisees who were with him heard him say this and asked, "What? Are we blind too?" Jesus said, "If you were blind, you would not be guilty of sin; but now that you claim you can see, your guilt remains."

In those verses we are given a moral infantry of the Pharisees who were bad shepherds of Gods people. The interesting thing about these verses is that Jesus does not talk about the 'activities' of the bad shepherds or their theology, but their characters.

This is a very interesting question that reveals a lot about the Pharisees. They were unable to evaluate their own lives; they lived in denial, and could not cope with reality. They were blind to their blindness. They were unable to correctly evaluate their own spiritual condition. They found comfort in lying to themselves about themselves. A bad shepherd is some one who has a confused morality. Jesus said in response to the Pharisees question, "If you were blind you would not be guilty of sin." In other words your claim not to be blind makes you more calculable for your sin. Because you think you have spiritual insight and understanding, you are more more guilty of sin.
